Yea, but remember you have two types of conditions so the timeline won't be the same. When your doing MC make sure you can tell whether it is a Condition Precedent or Condition Subsequent.

There isn't really a difference, just a slight connection.
A condition will trigger a duty owed. Whether you have a condition precedent/ subsequent that event must occur for the contractual duty to arise. If the condition is not fulfilled, the duty does not arise, and therefore the parties are not contractually obligated to follow through with the prospective duty.

Your in a pickle. You could make this interesting, but I strongly suggest speaking with an attorney versed in real property law in your jurisdiction.
Ok, you are both liable for the loan 100%, even if the other does not pay. That being said, I would approach this individual and offer to assume their portion of the loan. By assuming their portion you are taking over the entire liability and releasing them from further contributions. BUT, in exchange for this assumption they must convey their 50% interest in the property to you by issuing a new deed. You MUST go to the mortgage company and inform them of this because it WILL trigger the acceleration clause in the contract you signed with them.
What this would do is, in exchange for taking on the burden of the entire loan and risk of foreclosure, give you 100% ownership of the home and after you sell it 100% of the profits. You have to go talk to a real estate attorney, I couldn't suggest that enough.

I would say if you can replace the engine and everything else needs to get that car to point where you have a "new used" car, then do it. There is no point really to take on that much debt for something new if you can repair something 1/3 which would get you in the same position really. Either way your going to end up with a "new car" of sorts.
I would also try and shop them, go to another spot and say I need this, I was quoted X price, could you do it for less. Biggest thing would be getting a warranty on the work done. You MUST negotiate some type of warranty that spans at least 3 years IMO. Don't be afraid to tell them no, and don't be afraid to negotiate with them on price and warranty.
Good luck.

Good, that is glad to hear. I have a co-worker who we just worked through this process actually; she was upside down though.
In your situation you should have no problem getting the car refinanced. When you refinance something you are basically taking the equity you have in the good and using it to get a more favorable loan term.
To figure out your equity take the FMV of the vehicle you read on Kelly Blue Book and subtract it from the balance of your loan, that will give you, roughly, the equity you have in your vehicle. I say roughly because car are very difficult to find a solid price on, rather then homes where there are more factors that go into computing the value.
So, like I said before you can go to a national or regional bank, or you can go to a local credit union as well. I suggest starting out at a local credit union because they will, typically, have more favorable interest rates as opposed to national banks. They may require you to open up a bank account, which isn't a problem ask them what the lowest amount is required to hold an account with them and open one.
Just be honest with them and tell them you want to apply for the loan in order to remove you off the current loan you have associated with the vehicle. Don't be afraid to "have your dad or brother" take a look at the specifics (insert whatever line you want) and just shop around for a low interest rate.
What you want to do is get the new loan for the 30-day pay off amount of the current loan on the vehicle. The bank/credit union will usually work with you on making that payment to the current loan holder and it sometimes moves faster because it is a certified payment instead of a personal check.
Then, you just continue to make payments on the new loan and forget about the old. Over time you should pay less for the vehicle for a few reasons, one you were making extra payments which saved you money on interest and by refinancing you are getting a lower interest rate which will lower the amount of interest accrued each month.

I haven't looked, there is still a lot of variables in the scenario. If they do their credit in house they will probably use the account receivables as a basis of factoring in the restructuring process. Your fine, you have nothing to worry about. Plus, as soon as they filed for Bankruptcy they had to stop everything associated with their business, excluding formalities and other business expenses. It's called the automatic stay, it's basically a halt on everything so the bankruptcy trustee can discern the timelines of when and what their powers extend too.

When you refinance something you are looking to take the equity you have in the good and use it to get a lower interest rate. They are a national chain that sells clothing, so I could image they have a large amount of credit accounts with high balances. Usually in a bankruptcy proceeding those outstanding credit accounts are sold at a discount to another company.
Also, it will depend on what type of bankruptcy proceeding they are seeking. They could go straight liquidation (Ch 7) or re-organization (Ch 11)--it will depend on a lot of factors.
There are a lot of things at play. I would suggest calling the number on the back and cancel your account. Looks like you can log on to your account at their website, maybe they have a way to close there.

As long as you disclose that all warranties are removed and your selling the vehicle as is, so long as the purchaser reasonably inspects the vehicle, they have no standing to claim warranty.
Edit: There are a lot of consumer protection laws that effect vehicle sales; that's why the window sticker says in big bold black font " SOLD AS IS," and unequivocally notifies the consumer.
Now, if you sell it as it, but also make representations as to condition of the vehicle (ex. No flood damage), if the purchaser later finds out the car was in fact damaged because of a flood--they would have standing to file a legal suit based on contractual misrepresentation.
Warranties and contractual defenses are two completely separate issues.

Bullshit. You can invest in property without a conventional loan. Find someone who owns their home, willing to sell, and buy that shit owner financed. You more or less have a job, keep making money, and live there while you fix up the place with the $10,000 you have stashed. Be creative, guy.
I would go after those grad school loans you have incurred, but only if they are higher interest rate then your undergrad. Those are ALL good ideas.

The best loan doesn't exist, pay cash and get scholarships if you can.
If you can't, Federal backed loans have the most flexibility. If you sign up with FAFSA, later when your finished with school you have a grace period before your first payment is due. If you can't begin paying or some other life event happens, you can put your loans in forbearance. Forbearance is basically a pause on you paying for a determined period of time.
Once you accept the loan your loan will begin to accrue interest at the rate set for your loan.
NOW...that's Federal...if you go with a commercial loan, you are locked in and required to pay. There are no grace periods, no forbearance, etc.
Commercial loans/lenders are out to make money. Student loans are NON-dishchargable in bankruptcy so you are required to pay them off. Commercial loans also DO NOT have Forgiveness programs like the Federal loans DO.

I have to put a disclaimer on this post: I am not an attorney and you should go and talk to one before you set things up. First, when you go talk to an attorney about setting up a business, so long as you actually start that business, those fees associated with the counsel can be deducted under the start-up-business deduction. Second, the main and most important difference between a C and S Corp is the way the taxes are implemented. For a C-Corp there is the traditional double-layer of taxes, once at the corp. level and then second at the shareholder level. Your going to pay taxes at the corp. level depending on the yearly gross income, and then each shareholder will be taxes at their own respective rate based on their bracket. Now for a S-Corp. there is only one level of taxation. Taking a S-election turns the Corp. into a flow-through entity and removes the double taxation, which allows the shareholder to only be taxed once on the dividend they receive at their respective bracket. Third, you have to remember a few things, a) S-Election allows you to deduct a lot more of the costs associated with running the corp. and b) Shareholders are the owners of the corporation by way of the stock certificates.
